body: Nice!
The goal is to get projects using the same license file.
Opps, approved before noticing the Travis failures.
@m-g-k @mbwhite Can you assign a reviewer to this, please?
Hi Dan, can you post a sample bna that does this so I can take a look at it please?
Try this CTO file: https://models.accordproject.org/finance/bond.html
Hi, thanks for the report - I'll try and push a new version with a fix out later today

This was caused by an underlying problem in the composer-common library used by the plugin and has already been fixed there. So just updating the plugin to use the latest composer-common has fixed this. Please install the v0.19.8 version which includes the fix. This has just been pushed to the marketplace so the install should happen automatically.

Yep working on it - hopefully in a day or so it will be there. FYI, you can install the v0.19.1 release manually from the release page if you are really stuck for a new version until I get it onto the marketplace from the release page here: [v0.19.1](https://github.com/hyperledger/composer-vscode-plugin/releases/download/v0.19.1/composer-support-client-0.19.1.vsix)
v0.19.1 has now been published to the marketplace. Normal service resumed :-)
Please do not merge until Mark has approved the new license check version
LGTM, don't need to wait for Mark ;-)

**Abstract**
Currently there is no unit test for the VSCode composer server extension, this story is for adding unit tests for the VSCode composer server extension.  The unit test will allow us to verify the extension functions with confidence.

Hi Fenglian,
I briefly reviewed the code of this extension and I'm happy to find these problems here as an issue ;-) Test coverage is not really present.
If I find time, I'd be happy to help you with that.
Once time, I will put a pull request regarding (unit) tests and modularisation/refactoring in general.
I mean this in a general way, also regarding issue #60, #58, #59, #62 and so on.
Close this one as it is covered by story #58

Currently, to work with models that use imports and span multiple files, you must open all related files. To validate the ACL files and query files, the corresponding model files must also be opened as well. I plan to improve this by allowing a folder to be opened, but from what you say, it sounds like it is working as designed.

If you make this work with just the folder opened, that sounds fine to me. I always open the entire folder in vscode anyway, and I think it makes sense.

But opening each file separately, I would not call it "as designed" (at least I hope not), but rather a "Known Limitation" :)
Fair point, "Known Limitation" is more accurate :-)

I am on vscode hyperledger composer plugin 0.19.1 and it is May 2018. So this annoying issue has not yet been fixed. Is there any plan to fix this? IF there is a limitation on this tool, then why even hyperledger composer folks are recommending this tool?
Screw this plugin! Why recommending something that can't be used properly! That's even worse!
I guess there is not much incentive to fix this as composer is also being discontinued.

> composer is also being discontinued

I'm new to this, is it gonna be discontinued soon :-O

@namgk It's not being discontinued, but IBM decided to focus more on Fabric itself.
It's still there, still open source and alive. It just won't receive much investment from IBM.

Yes, you are correct, I will do this tomorrow. Thanks for the report! 

I'll just wait for the latest (but currently draft) 0.14.1 release which is due tomorrow before I push the new version
This is now fixed in the latest release (0.14.1).

Adds the ability to use the newer blue theme for UML diagrams by specifying 
`"composer.UML.diagramTheme": "blue"`
in the user settings.

Also simplifies options settings from "pUML" to just "UML"
LGTM, have installed MGKs build of the plugin and tried it out - nice work!

Closing as discussed with @m-g-k who is going to push this and other changes in on Monday.

Hi @theophoric what version of the plugin were you using when you saw the above error? The latest 0.9.1 plugin version has been updated with the Composer v0.9.0 parser and so you need to use this version to use the updated transactions and events syntax that you show above.

Hi @pd93 thanks for raising this.  It is not quite true that for _all_ errors the whole file is highlighted. In fact exceptions thrown by the underlying composer parser may have a Line/Column number in them or not. If they do, then only the error is highlighted, whereas if they do not then the whole file is highlighted as the location is not known - see examples below and unfortunately, I have to rely on the base parser to locate the error for highlighting.

However, I hear your pain over this it hits me too and to fix this the underlying composer parser needs to issue file and line numbers for more errors. I raised issue #321 on base composer on this for a particular cto exception, and also base issue #382 is open which covers this for ACL files. So let's keep this issue open but blocked until the underlying base defects are fixed, then we can see where we are. I also suggest you comment on these base issues, to raise their priority in the composer team

This acl error shows when a keyword is not matched
![acl](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11261488/27185090-222f20ae-51dc-11e7-961f-7f4ce2bee785.png)

cto keyword not matched
![cto](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11261488/27185091-2237515c-51dc-11e7-9508-d1deab9a7007.png)

cto "id" not matched, highlights whole block (not whole file)
![cto2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11261488/27185092-2237d938-51dc-11e7-8006-fd89039623e0.png)

@m-g-k Hi. Yeah I've noticed since raising this that a few of the errors **do** infact work as expected. It seems to  be `namespace` and `undeclared type` errors that are causing this the most often for me.

I'll be sure to upvote the issues in the base repo. Thanks
@m-g-k Thought I'd update this in case you hadn't seen that #321 has been closed with Composer v0.8.1
Yeah, thanks I'll take a look and report back...

@pd93 FYI, I've just pushed a new release of the vscode plugin (0.8.2) that contains the composer-common fix for #321 but this still does not address the issue for ACL files (and indeed some types of error in .cto files as well) so I'll keep this issue open until at least the ACL fix for #382 has been made.
